segments.text: Now, I think where we ended rather abruptly yesterday was that I was asking you to make some comparison, if you could, between Scripps when you came here and Scripps as it is now.
Well, at that time it was quite small.
I think the number of faculty at the time was 15.
And it was all tightly knit group and under very direct collaboration.
contact in research and thinking and development with Roger Revelle, who was the director at the time.
Whereas now, of course, it's grown tremendously.
It is a huge organization.
And there is no longer the closeness and concerted overall institute action that was possible at the time.
Did you think there was a, it's a poor choice of words possibly, but do you think there was more leeway or more freedom in research then than there is now?
Not due to institutional restrictions at all.
No, complete freedom then, complete freedom now.
I was not thinking so much of institutional restrictions as I was thinking an ability to sort of move from project to project possibly.
Well, that is always limited by the availability of funds.
Probably there is more funds going into research today than in those days.
But science has become, first of all, much more expensive to do.
Instrumentation and costs of doing everything has risen sky high.
And furthermore, the individual freedom in seeking research projects of fundamental interest
has been very much strongly curtailed these days in the country as a whole than they were then.
How's that?
Well, I think it's a long story.
Essentially, the era in the 50s and the 60s was a great development of science in the United States after the war.
The country realized from the war experience what a fundamental role that knowledge has
in making the nation strong and the sponsoring by ONR of science.
ONR sponsored essentially all oceanographic science in those days.
So I undertake it then that you feel like that a decrease in funding by ONR has in effect limited one's individual research process.
Well, it's not that simple.
In those days, essentially, the nation saw fit.
But through ONR, for example, first and later on as the National Science Foundation was founded a couple of years later, to dramatically increase the volume of scientific research in the country.
And of course, that growth could not go on forever.
What happened was, of course, in the very useful growth, there is also a wild flora of less useful developments.
And what made the crisis occur, essentially, crisis in the attitude of the citizen as a whole, citizen of the country, toward science and scientists.
was when the illusions were broken, essentially, during the conflict of the Vietnam War.
And that is when the illusions that people had about the ethical stance and the objectivity of scientists
And in addition, their responsibilities as human beings were seriously being questioned.

People saw particularly that military support of scientific research was not entirely a blessing, that there were strings attached in some cases, even though fundamental research was often involved, and that the scientists essentially went where the money was, didn't necessarily follow
what they were compelled to feel ethically.

And essentially, that whole crisis then led to a strongly decreased confidence in that scientists can be trusted with the leadership of the country that people thought of them before as some kind of omniscience.

perfected idealistic human beings and many of them didn't come out that way furthermore obviously growth must stop sometime and as a result essentially there were some years of terrible turmoil where everything was reorganized and as a result it's very difficult to
Great difficulties were created in carrying out some of the scientific research.
And in the reorganization, essentially, that has emerged from that, the project research is what has risen.
I can understand that.
The individual scientist is no longer trusted with the judgment of what is good or bad for the nations.
Some scientists are very good in judging that.
Others are not.
And everybody has to carry the blame
for the bad ones.

And instead, then, the emphasis is on large projects where any single individual does not carry so much weight, but which are also then becoming often less imaginative, tremendously burdened down with enormous bureaucratic apparatus.
And although, therefore, much, much more money goes into science now than maybe in dollars than in 1950s,
or even 60s, the effective input, I think, is much smaller today.
You mean a combination of bureaucratic costs plus rising inflation?
Rising inflation, bureaucratic costs, the loss of imaginative approach that you have when everything is molded into huge programs,
that are run from some kind of centralized bureaucracy.
Some of these projects are very good, and they're in an imaginative way.
Others become characterized by tremendous inertia and preservation mainly of business as usual.
There is, of course, a whole spectrum of judgments, possibly.
But I think that's on the average is a correct situation.

Do you think that the bringing together or the making of institutions to grow in size, that's very poorly put, but the increase in size of research institutions has also created this concept of one major project or two or three major projects with a carefully designed goal?
I don't think so at all.
For example, Scripps was already quite large when this development happened.

and was and has always been a quite anarchic institution of a number of different scientists with different ideas that during the time when Roger Revelle was director was all kept together by one spirit.
Later they were carrying on on their own and mostly in quite a good fashion.
It could be done.

it was quite possible to carry out, in that situation, individual research projects of different size, some quite small, one-man projects, others much larger, and many of them depending on the unique facilities here, the ships and other things.
So the institutional structure has not forced this retransformation, the reorganization.
It is essentially the nation's way of thinking about what the research is, what it's good for,
and what scientists are, and what they should be charged with, what responsibilities they should be charged with.
That is what has changed.
And it's for the good and for the bad.
Do you see an expanding non-goal-oriented funds for, let's say, space and oceanography in the near future?
Well, in space, there must be
They must be goal-oriented, because to go out in space and work, you really need that.
Their project orientation is absolute necessity.
Everybody can't go out in his own spaceship and play around.
So their profound organization has to characterize everything.
In oceanography, the only organization you need is the institutional one.
The institution holds available ships and all facilities.
It doesn't need any national organization.
a huge bureaucracy to do that.
So in space, that must continue.
In oceanography, you see more and more nationwide projects.
Some of them are very useful because they bring together people in the same field, like the GeoSEX program, for example, or the NORPAC program.
But in others, it hampers the development.
There's this artificial requirement that you must, for some reason,
bring together heterogeneous groups from all over the place.
Do you see an increase or a decrease in international cooperation in oceanography?
I think the international cooperation is probably gradually increasing.
There are, particularly through projects such as IPOD, the deep-sea drilling internationalized project, and there are several other ones, I think, where
at least some, there's some semblance to international collaboration.
And in space, too, of course, there's some, at least theatrical attention paid to the same thing, but not in the, I think, in the truly scientific way, but in some kind of public relations way.
Do you feel as if the developing third world countries
and their demands for 200-mile limits and their distrust of what amounts to attitudes and goals of more highly developed nations?
Do you feel as if that would begin to limit your research?
Well, that's an interesting question.
First of all, the third country nations have always, that's a field where Scripps has always played a great role in receiving scientists from these emerging countries.
nations and to train them here, or to give them additional training to what they have obtained elsewhere, so that they can go back and contribute to the growing organizations in their home country.
Mexico, the People's Republic of China, Japan, many people have come here and learned, and others have come here for collaboration.

The new regulations you mentioned on the 200 mile limit, obviously that throws in another bureaucratic complication into the previously free roaming, possibilities of roaming around free over the ocean.
But that's deplorable, I think.
Any increased bureaucracy is just terrible.
But one can also understand these countries.
It is very clear to them that there is no
that there is no clear-cut limit between scientific research and what this scientific research is used for.
They've seen numerous examples of that.
And when they particularly have seen the nefarious interaction or secret interaction of the US in the internal affairs of various countries, it's understandable that they're afraid.
that discoveries of resources in their territorial waters, for example, will bring them into the limelight as an interesting place where certain things will not be allowed to happen.
Or if they were less important in the past, they would be allowed to happen.
So I can understand why this paranoia is growing up.
And the best thing we could do as a nation, it seems to me, is to mitigate the situation by
increasing the trust and the feeling of responsibility from the side of our nation that these people feel.
If they trust us, there will be no difficulty, or not so much difficulty at least, in getting the necessary permit to operate in their waters or even to make permanent arrangements.
Okay, now, in terms of space,
then away from the oceans into space for a second, do you see an increase in international cooperation occurring there?
In space?
In space.
Certainly at the level of international discussions and conferences.
mutual participation, research.
But there's not much more you could do beyond that because, again, the specialized nature of the expeditions.
There could be USSR members of, say, cosmonaut team, but there's less and less space research done with cosmonauts.
It's done with unmanned probes, so there is not
much need, essentially, not much improvement that would be obtained by making hybrid instrumentation packages.
In some cases, it could be.
And there is such a collaboration, for example, between the German space agency and the USA Space Agency in the exploration of comets, for example, where the Germans have

advanced power and the U.S. is less far advanced and the possibility then for U.S. investigators to place instrumentation on Russian spacecraft and vice versa and German spacecraft and vice versa has been quite fruitful.
I don't know if it will increase much in that respect with regard to USSR.
I think there is still quite a lot of mistrust between the nations and

and also the interlocking, the close relationship between military intelligence or military applications of space science and the information you derive from space experiments, from some space experiments, will add a touch of touchiness to those questions also in the future.
Has there been, in your opinion, much uneasiness concerning the close relationship of the military and oceanography and the military and space among scientists?
Well, in space, first of all, that development took place so late that the country has drawn a lesson and kept rather
rather watertight separation between the civilian applications of space science and the military applications and the intelligence applications.
So with regard to execution of the programs, there is no interaction at all.
The justification of the civilian space program had some overtones of the attending military
advantages.
So I can say it was a pity that it wasn't possible to man a scientific research program without having that aspect contributing.
But that's not so bad, it seems to me.
If something like that could be helpful.
In the case of oceanography,
Again, in the case of the interaction of the Navy, for example, with oceanographic program, I think that's always been a very, very constructive interaction.
And the tradition in the Navy, not only in this country, but in other countries, has always been one of the most research-minded
organizations and research for its own sake.
So I think, on average, I don't think there have been very bad, particularly bad repercussions there.
Of course, when one thinks about the thing in more subtle details, it has effects.
One can always ask, how is one's
independent judgment of political, military issues, colored by the fact that you receive, for example, all your support from a military organization.
I think subconsciously it is affecting many people directly, so that their unbiased thinking is not so unbiased.
That is, of course, a negative aspect.
But it

It must be said that the Navy bears, the Office of Naval Research bears or takes the credit for beginning and carrying the early scientific armament, rearmament in the civilian sense, in the fundamental scientific sense of US oceanography.
And in the present situation, the UNR has decreased its role substantially.
It is now, as you know, all the armed forces
Agencies have been forced by legislation to support only mission-oriented.
They've been able to prove that the research that you do with support from the armed forces is clearly mission-oriented.
And that's fine.
They need for security and defense and attack.
Because it's also called defense.
Specific information.
And it seems to me that's one of the purposes of the institutions of the country to provide what the government legitimately needs.
But it's important to keep that, I think, separate from scientific activities.
And again, it's groups that has been done insofar as all these mission-oriented activities are
kept in a separate organization and separate from the campus.
This was not done on an absolutely voluntary basis, although the separation has always been partially done.
It was largely catalyzed by the student protest during the 60s.
At the University of California San Diego?
Right.
And I think that's when classified research stopped being done, is that correct?
When it stopped being done on campus.
It's still being done to a quite large extent off campus.

In these veins of political geography and political oceanography, do you feel uneasy ever about the fact that scientists serve as consultants for private enterprise and for military as well for the academic campus?
No, I think on the contrary.
A consultation done by scientists is really one of the ways to keep in touch with the real world.
And scientists otherwise tend very easily to become too theoretical or irresponsible.
If you are allowed to build airplanes that never have to fly, then it's possible that the design is not so crucially thought about.
If the airplane has to fly, then
other pressures on you to really solve problems in a realistic fashion.
Correct me if I'm summing this up incorrectly.
It's an awful phrase.
Again, you see Scripps Institution of Oceanography, then.
You see their job as a combination of work in military, private enterprise, and private sciences.
If you should like a public institution serving all three sectors of society.
No, I think that...
Scripps as it is should, although it entirely does it, should serve only civilian and scientific purposes.
Then if the staff places their capabilities at the disposal of industry or to the government as consultants,
They do that normally, but you have to, by rule, take leave of absence or vacation while you do that, or do it when you're not serving the university.
So that's very important, of course, that you deprive the taxpayers of the service that you have to give them.
And particularly since most people use the proceeds of consultation for their own personal income,
and more rarely for the benefit of the university.
Now, when you came here, Roger Revelle was the director.
Is that correct?
Yes.
And he remained director until he actually went off to Harvard.
He sort of wore two hats here for a while.
That's true.
OK. Have you noticed any abrupt change between the direction of the institution under Revelle and then after his successors?
No, no, everybody's tried to do the best they can, they could, in their own way, and each one of the directors have contributed very great things.
For example, again, Roger Wells' greatness were particularly in the tremendous inspiration that he gave to everybody and his ability to amalgamate
and weld everybody together into a joint effort in fields of importance.
In these efforts, perhaps, he did not have time or so much understanding for the importance of sophisticated scientific facilities.
He had largely a Puritan instinct that science should be done in an inexpensive fashion, which is very commendable.
But for many things in modern science, that's not so easy.
Cyclotrons are hard to make out of old pipes and things like that.
Professor Nirenberg, Director Nirenberg, for example, has done a tremendous job in two fields particularly that I can see, probably more.
But the two that particularly stand out in my mind are his bringing scripts into the computer era, into the proper handling of data.
Previously, in the enthusiasm of doing things, lots of data were collected on shipboard, and then forgotten, and could not, the way they were handled and stored, you could never retrieve them.
Now, thanks to Director Nirenberg, essentially, computers were installed on board.
All information that was, which is so voluminous that it's bound to be lost unless you do something special, was immediately retrievable, and that has been immensely advantageous.
Also the introduction of online computers in campus laboratories and on shipboard has been much stimulated by him.

And also the creation in the institution of a very well-organized analytical facility that has a wide range of sophisticated instrumentation that is difficult for each individual and his contract or anything to justify, but which serves the whole community at the recharge
including students, has been one of the really great developments that he's done.
So each one has contributed in its own way, I think.
All right.
Of what sort of computers is he installed now?

Medium-sized computers of various kinds that are on board of the ships so that you can put in, first of all, all the navigation, and you can relate the navigation and the positions to the scientific data.
That was something that in old times took
many months to go through the ship's logs and find out where were you when you found such and such a thing, exactly.
Now it's all there right away.
Where did other institutions already utilize computers on shipboard?
That was essentially the theme of the era.
And that happened simultaneously, I think, at other institutions.
But I'm not sure that it's been so thoroughly carried out as here.
But I wouldn't swear on that.
Look at their facilities.
Had other nations utilized computers on shipboard before the United States?
Again, it came at the same time.
And particularly in France and Germany have always been rather advanced in the field.
The USSR has been lagging behind, but I think it is coming up again.
But the US has certainly, the United States have been leading in this because of their leading role both in software and hardware development.
It has been suggested in another interview that possibly the age of the great explorations of oceans is over.
Because with the introduction of computers, shipboard, and so forth, that more and more analyzing of data will have to be done back in labs and this sort of thing.
That the old idea of the oceanographer at sea
maybe through.
I don't think so at all.
No, I don't think so at all.
And particularly with sophisticated ships, with large ships that are essentially floating laboratories, you can do more and more experimental work on board.
That is
